title: Before 2018, will Tesla file for bankruptcy or begin restructuring its debt in a corporate workout?
preds: It will take some significant bad press on the safety of its cars to force a restructure of their debt before year's end.

Deep pockets and free money cause it all to last longer, but Tesla has serious issues. The cars have too many accidents, with too much damage and catch fire too easily. As result insurers will multiply coverage fees (a major Dutch one changed the fee from 750 to 5000 a year). Next to that there are the production issues with the new model. And I cannot imagine the cheaper model has less issues than the more expensive one. So, no, not before 2018, probably not even before 2019, but in 2018 it will become widely known Tesla is just not good enough technically and that is basically end of story.

Tesla would exhaust cash on Aug. 6 .Tesla’s financial needs mean it is blowing through more than $1 billion a quarter thanks to massive investment in making the Model 3, a $35,000 car that’s looking less likely to generate a return anytime soon. “Whether they can last another 10 months or a year, he needs money, and quickly,” said Kevin Tynan, senior analyst with Bloomberg Intelligence, who estimates Tesla will be required to raise at least $2 billion in fresh capital by mid-2018.

So, I'm wondering how this question would look if we broke Telsa down into its subsidiaries.  It appears that Tesla in regards to its EV business has subsidiaries in the United States, Germany, Canada, Australia, Denmark, France, Hong Kong, Italy, Japan, Monaco, Singapore, Switzerland, Taiwan, and the UK.  Also if we look at Tesla as more than just an EV company, e.g., as an energy capture and storage company, we see subsidiaries such as SolarCity.  
https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1318605/000119312511054847/dex211.htm I'm guessing that Tesla's German subsidiary will face the most resistance and competition. The competition in the lower-cost model (Model 3)  will determine the winner in the EV market in Germany.

Tesla Admits SolarCity Is Undergoing A 'Financial Restructuring' So, the question is whether a financial restructuring meets the definition of a corporate workout. Question description:  Scrutiny increased with Tesla’s acquisition of SolarCity in 2016 (Bloomberg, Market Watch). Actions by Tesla or its wholly-owned subsidiaries, including SolarCity, will count, regardless of the country where the bankruptcy filing or corporate workout takes place. Consider this also:   https://www.fool.com/investing/2017/04/20/why-investors-should-have-known-teslas-solarcity-a.aspx

At the current stock market valuation they should be able to secure debt easily for the the next 1-5 years, unless there is a black swan event or it comes out that some or much of what they have been promising is undeliverable.

The probability of insolvency is pretty low before 2018 because
1) Tesla is showing growth.
2) its debt to equity ratio may increase but the positive expectations will keep the company floating for a long time.

Is there a scenario where a company such as Alphabet or Apple would seek to integrate with Tesla's production capabilities, either or both, high-density batteries or EV cars?  The established competitors in the auto market have developed production capabilities acquired through the manufacture of ICE cars.  How would that integration occur?  Would it involve an informal workout and debt restructuring? Regarding Tesla’s bonds, there are issues expiring in 2018, 2019 and 2021.  Those issues have an S&P credit rating of B- (high credit risk).  Accordingly, Tesla has only the option of offering stock and that’s what they did.  Now, there’s some question whether the capital raise this time around was sufficient.  One could suppose that there would be another successful attempt to raise cash in 2017 or by 2nd quarter of 2018.  Is there a scenario where the pattern of initially not raising sufficient cash makes sense in the overall picture in Tesla's evolution and in what way does it make sense? Overall, is integration a likely scenario and if it is, what is the timeframe for this scenario to materialize? https://seekingalpha.com/article/4001655-tesla-just-said
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-04-14/apple-gets-dmv-approval-to-test-self-driving-cars-in-california

Tesla is rated B- by S&P. Historically default risk for company rated B has been c.4.5% over next year, although much lower over last decade c.2.5% for 2006-2015 even taking into account spike in 2009. Tesla at the weak end of B range. Risk jumps markedly if drops to CCC or lower (c.24%), although many of these companies will be in terrible condition (almost by definition).
http://www.spratings.com/documents/20184/774196/2015+Annual+Global+Corporate+Default+Study+And+Rating+Transitions/6d311074-5d56-4589-9ef8-a43615a6493b
Bloomberg estimates the risk of default in next year at 0.2%, which seems very low.
Looking at the 2016 10-k annual report, the company had unrestricted cash of over $3bn at the end of 2016 (and has just raised another $1.2bn) and limited refinancing requirements this year. However, it is spending at rapid rate developing the Model 3: free cash outflow of $1.1bn in Q4 16.

I’m uncertain if the following thought experiment is relevant to the resolution of the question within its time frame but is it worthwhile to evaluate the two approaches to production within various components of the Tesla business model, e.g., with today’s geopolitical reality is one approach, vertical integration versus outsourcing, better than the other?   Apple took the outsourcing pathway to production and has been very successful.  In contrast, Tesla has opted for vertical integration for EV production but has not yet completed that integration in its manufacture of high energy density storage batteries.  Tesla's partner (and underwriter?) on the Gigafactory is Panasonic.  For the supply chain, Panasonic relies on Sumitomo Metal Mining.  And yes, I understand that the reality is that there are varying degrees of overlap of the two endpoints and the trend appears to be moving toward greater vertical integration for this particular entity. Lithium production appears to be the key link in the battery supply chain, or rather, that portion of the supply chain focused on cathode manufacture.  This portion is currently outside of Tesla’s control.   Now, we can cast various plausible scenarios involving the dilemma posed by North Korea’s insistence in being “the mouse that roared”.  Others can figure out the probabilities of these scenarios but suppose military action is one outcome likely to occur.  What effect will that development pose to the supply chain and will that effect reverberate through the supply chain sufficient to pose a danger to Tesla’s current business configuration? Ok, that’s out there but so what?  My view is that we could say that there are some technologists out there who we could consider the new alchemists in that they’re working on the age-old problem of transcending our primate nature.  That primarily involves new ways of thinking or man-machine integration.  (Media theorist, Marshall McLuhan in 1967 pointed out this integration as I'm sure others before him, e.g., Vladimir Vernadsky.  McLuhan referred to technology as extensions of the human body while for Vernadsky the emphasis was on something he called the noosphere.) The seed of the above thought experiment grew from the following article:  http://seekingalpha.com/article/4056248-lithium-evs-teslas-outsourcing-vs-toyotas-vertical-integration?app=1&auth_param=1dvndc:1ccpn5s:b97325622e131947d8b9f228386eed20&dr=1#alt2
(Article title --Lithium: Tesla's Outsourcing Vs. Toyota's Vertical Integration) Btw, we can see that Nature has various strategies to deal with a changing world.  One of those strategies, albeit hardwired, is K selection versus r selection for reproductive survival (or r/K selection theory).

How much does the cult of personality weigh into the prediction?  Ideally, couldn’t one test one’s personal prediction model by separating out a factor at a time and then assessing the whole?  For instance, let’s separate out the cult of personality and look at the fundamentals.  Or, is the power of an icon a fundamental as well?  There’s just no getting around the idea that cult of personality has hefty carrying power.  Look at Steve Jobs and Apple.    The 1984 Apple commercial... what a bit of magic!  The idea of selling the computer as a symbol of liberating power rather than its opposite.  That’s only part of the story, though.  It was Microsoft who provided the $150 million investment to save Apple.
http://www.businessinsider.com/how-steve-jobs-took-apple-from-near-bankruptcy-to-billions-in-13-years-2011-1 Let’s set aside the question of the impact of merging ideas with a face.  What about other questions? What needs to be done and what can be done?  How much cash is required and how soon is it needed?

Shares of Tesla (TSLA.O) dropped on Monday after a downgrade by Goldman Sachs, bringing the electric carmaker's decline to 11 percent since its quarterly report last week stoked worries about how much cash it is using to launch its Model 3 sedan. Concerns that Tesla's Model 3 production this year might be delayed, as well as expectations the company will sell stock to raise $1.7 billion, led Goldman Sachs analyst David Tamberrino to downgrade Tesla to "sell" from "neutral".
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-markets-tesla-idUSKBN16624D
Elon Musk probably has the ability to raise money and avoid bankruptcy or restructuring. It will take more than a couple of analysts who recommend shorting Tesla to convince me things are that bad.

Tesla will need to raise capital through a stock sale. However, there seems to be a federal investigation being underway on SolarCity, which would make it extremely difficult (or impossible) to raise capital through a stock offering. Secondly, SolarCity will start to increase the cash burn rate as it takes the Buffalo solar module plant online. 2017 will be  a tough year for solar module manufacturer as price will plummet to record lows. This will be a big hinderance to SolarCity being able to sell its' new modules to third party buyers or to use them in their own roof systems (because the higher price will make them uncompetitive against SunPower, etc.).  Secondly, Tesla will need to show that it can actually deliever the Model 3, which is doubtful given the company's trackrecord so far. As the re-tooling of the Freemont factory progresses, it will be intersting to see if the start of manufacturing of the Model 3 will happen in 2017. Lastly, the Gigafactory in Nevada will require about an additional $1billion to finish.  In the whole picture, this is unlikely to result in a full-scale bankruptcy without any unknown intervening factors, such as a material reduction in demand. However, a restructuring of the revolving credit loan facility is more than likely to happen to ensure that Tesla can proceed with it' current losses. It will all depend on how large and successful the stock offering is during the first half of 2016.

It is very unlikely that Tesla will file for bankruptcy. Even though Musk can't keep up with his production targets, as long as Tesla can produce cars and keep selling them the shareholders will not go into a panic mode and sell sell sell.  However, the stiff competition among the auto industry is worrying and Tesla needs to get model 3 out asap as that's the company's first affordable family car so that their company can expand into different target audiences.  I will keep this updated in case something changes. SCTY however, might need to restructure its debt but now with Tesla's acquisition it will be fine for a while

Tesla has strong access to capital markets to continue raising funds if their cash burn continues. Products are very good and in high demand - this should not change. An economic recession would severely affect Tesla but I see the chances of that happening being low

Estimated cash burn in Q4 was $1bn.  Cash flow (earnings before interest and taxes) in 2017 will be a negative $600 million on revenues of $10.5 billion.  However, depreciation and amortization are noncash charges, and those items will add back $1 billion, so 2017 EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) should be a positive $400 million.  Including capital expenditures, cash reserves on the balance sheet will fall from $2.2 billion at the end of 2016 to $900 million by the end of 2017.  This sets up another capital raise, which will be dilutive, but there is no indication that Tesla won't be able to access capital markets in 2017, and it has a sizable asset-based credit line secured by its finished goods inventory.   Therefore, the company should be able to avoid bankruptcy or a debt restructuring.   Much of the bankruptcy talk in the media is from short sellers who will profit if the stock declines precipitously.  The stock could fall to $40, which would certainly make the short sellers happy, but not likely to $0.

Tesla's Z-score is 6% (https://www.macroaxis.com/invest/ratio/TSLA--Probability_Of_Bankruptcy). As this is the probability for bankruptcy in the next 2 years, I multiply the Z-score by (2-1-1.5/12) to arrive at a (first & rough) default probability for 2017.

Tesla is 13 years old (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesla,_Inc.), during which time is has not filed for Bankruptcy (despite being extremely close to doing so in late 2008). The leadership which lead it through that turmoil is still in charge (most notably, Elon Musk). That indicates to me that a weak prior on Tesla defaulting this year is less than 1/13, and the inside view (TSLA is in much better shape than it has been throughout much of its history) suggests that it is slightly less than that.
